metadata.title: 7 Types of New Years Resolution Tweets | by Peter Licari, PhD | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 7 Types of New Years Resolution Tweets
metadata.description: It’s the start of a new year! People are changing out calendars, reaching out to loved ones, and deciding on what resolutions they want to try and hold themselves to this year. And if people are…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: what the most popular resolutions are
how achieving them won’t make us happy

all_paragraphs: It’s the start of a new year! People are changing out calendars, reaching out to loved ones, and deciding on what resolutions they want to try and hold themselves to this year. And if people are doing something (anything really), you can bet that a decent number of them are tweeting about it.

There are articles out there about what the most popular resolutions are, how achieving them won’t make us happy, and how we’re probably not going to achieve them anyways. Cheery. I decided that nothing really looks at how people approach the whole resolution enterprise. So for that, I took to Twitter and using some good ol’ computational social science decided to look at how people were approaching the idea of resolutions. What are the topics to twitterers tweet about in relation to resolutions? What are the most common words in those topics? Does it say anything about how we approach the idea of resolutions? Those are the questions we’re going to answer today.

Just a quick word before delving in. Although this project uses techniques from computational social science, I’m not racing to stamp the label of “science” on it. This is what I’m emphatically NOT saying: “Computer algorithms show that there are only 7 types of New Years resolution tweets. Here’s what they are thanks to Big Data™.” Instead, it’s just a fun way to get a sense of some broader patterns that existed out in the Twitterverse encircling new years resolutions.

Using Twitter’s API, I searched for tweets containing #newyearsresolutions2019, #resolutions, #newyearsresolution, #newyearsresolutions (yes, there was a difference) and any tweet that contained the words “new years resolutions” without awkwardly cramming them into a hashtag. I started collecting data around 12:00 PM December 31st and did the last pull just after 12:00 AM January 1st. The earliest tweets dated as far back to December 22nd and, thanks to the magic of time-zones, extended into 5:17 AM January 1st. This process yielded 41,502 unique tweets. I wasn’t exactly methodical about when I made the pulls because I was too busy enjoying saying goodbye to 2018. In accordance with the primer before, take this with a grain of salt.

After cleaning the data (removing stop words and punctuation, stemming the text, removing htmls, etc), I used Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) to model the latent topics in the tweets. LDA assumes that there is a fixed number of topics present across all of the documents in a corpus — which, in our case, are all of the tweets that we scraped — and allows for there to be multiple topics presented in a single document. The method then tells you the probability of any particular word appearing in a topic. So there might be a probability of .0002 that “apple” appears in the first topic and a probability that it pops up with a probability of .05 in the second topic (presumably, the data derives from an apple-enthusiast forum). You can take the most popular of these words, investigate when they crop up together, and get a sense of when

There’s a caveat with LDA. You have to choose how many topics exist in the data in order to implement it. It’s also up to us to determine what those topics mean. While there are ways to get a good sense of the right number of topics, attempting them in this data resulted in over 25 different topics. This intuitively makes sense but, frankly, makes for bad blog posts. I started seeing increasingly diminishing returns in how much the models explained after, like, 7 — so that’s the number I went with. Again, not scientific, but suffices for some fun.

People love to read and they love to write. Or, at the very least, the love to want to read and want to write. Reading and writing more are pretty common resolutions, so this one didn’t surprise me so much.
“One of my quiet resolutions for 2019 is to avoid online discussions about the writing process and instead spend some of that time actually reading or writing.” — SheerHubris

“Contemplating life… I want to run more, eat less, laugh more, stress less, sing more, shout less, hear more, speak less, read more, scroll less, write more, text less #NewYearsResolutions #writer #writinggoals” — Grumpy_SENCO

Self-care and love was another topic for resolution tweets. People have been paying more attention to mental-health over the last year. It did my heart good to see people concerned with taking care of themselves.
“new years resolutions: — no swearing — make more friends — be happier — get to healthier weight — do good in my a levels — find myself” — PaizuriRS

“new years resolution: to genuinely love myself & continue to have self growth. i’ve definitely grown a lot this year, but i want to continue to be happier, healthier, and become a much more mature individual. to always spread positivity & treat people with kindness, always.” — silhouettehaz
That last one touches on the next topic on our list, providing a nice demonstration of the fact that even small texts can touch on multiple things!

People aren’t just wishing themselves a happy new year, they’re wishing that others have one too! Although, I’d be lying if I implied that a decent proportion of tweets containing this topic didn’t come from brand accounts.

“HAPPY NEW YEAR! We sincerely wish you all endless happiness & success in 2019. It’s you year, your time is now, go & get it!!!! Thanks for all your love & support this year. Love Rach & Ry #HappyNewYear #NewYear2019 #NewYearsResolutions” — oppositetravel
“Happy New Year!! Cheers to your health and happiness!! #behappy #behealthy #newyearsresolutions #getfit #dontwait #livenow #beinthemoment #happyandhealthy #sharingiscaring” — AlohaRush

We take a break from your expected fare to bring you the first part of this analysis that made me go “huh.” The next group of words really had only one tweet associated with it. It turns out that it just happened to be one of the few tweets about New Years Resolutions to go viral.
Interestingly, none of these are actually dispositive of being a fascist -some are dispositive of being an ass- but it’s Twitter. Pith and snark is basically a requirement just to sign up.

This brings up an interesting question: Do retweets count for these kind of analyses? Too many of them will do exactly what happened here, construct a “topic” that’s basically just centered around the original tweet. But if that’s what people are actually doing while on Twitter, it’s important to know that too.

For what it’s worth, my opinion is that retweets are generally endorsements. Some people will use them to draw attention to an argument, but they’re mostly doing it to say “I feel this way too!” So I feel that it’s defensible here but a viral tweet can very clearly muck up the works for quantitative content analysis.

After that break-neck pivot in the tone of these topics, we turn to one a bit more commensurate with what you’d expect. People wanted to be better — but the emphasis was on the things they would give up. It’s less metamorphosing into a beautiful butterfly then it is to stop eating so much junk food so that we’d fit better into the cocoon.

So…the last day of 2018 already. Where does time go? Resolutions don’t always get kept but aiming to increase exercise, reduce processed meat & refined sugar, live in the moment, be kinder & spent time with those you love seems like a good plan to take into 2019. What about u? — ANDYC2311

Happy New Year! In addition to #keepingwildfishfree we are focusing on reducing #singleuseplastic and living #plasticfree in 2019, to keep our beautiful reefs (and planet) alive. What are your #NewYearsResolutions for 2019? What steps are you going to take to make them happen? — Savenemo

Contrary to popular opinion, most people aren’t solely out for themselves. (I mean, it’d be pretty hard for a social species to survive if it were entirely populated by sociopaths). A lot of people want to do good not just for themselves but for others.

“You know what I love, people that have the guts to advocate for the little guy. You know, the student who feels left out. Help them realize their full potential. Let’s make that our New Years resolution this year! #advocate #relentless #FLHornets #nextlevel #guts #fullpotential” — diversity54

Let me just put my cards out on the table here: For those who don’t know, I am a political science PhD candidate specializing in political behavior and psychology. Meaning that I have to put up with stuff pertaining to Trump — a lot. When I conceived of this project, I thought of it as a fun way to escape the ever-deepening pit of new lows excavated by the constant bombardment of controversy. On the other hand, President Trump spends more time on Twitter than in press briefings so I probably shouldn’t have been so surprised. Although I did feel a kinship with the subset of those who entered the topic from a place of exasperation.

“My New Years resolution is to make it my mission to support Speaker @NancyPelosi and @TheDemocrats as they fight against the fascist impulses of the Trump regime, champion a progressive agenda, and build for a HUGE 2020 victory. Who’s in? #NewYearsResolutions” -DemWrite

“How about the media and we, the public, make a promise and stop covering every tweet that @realDonaldTrump put out in 2019. Stop giving him the attention that he so desperately desires/craves. #NewYearsResolutions #notrumptweets” missangeleyes
“All you trump hating liberals should make a New Years resolution: stop being jealous, angry, hateful, pathetic poor excuses for human beings for 2019.” — Anthony14133926
And there you have it! The 7 types of New York Resolution Tweets!

I’ve put the annotated code for this analysis on my GitHub. (One of my resolutions for this year is to be better about posting there). Let me know what you think about this analysis down in the comments.

Peter R. Licari is a PhD student in Political Science at the University of Florida specializing in American Politics, Political Behavior, and Political Methodology. The opinions expressed are his own. He can also be found on YouTube and on Twitter(@prlitics13). What little spare time remains is dedicated to long-distance running, video games with his ever-patient wife, walking his dog, Dude, and holding oddly productive one-sided conversations with his cat, Asia.
Mastering Text Mining with R by Ashish Kumar and Avinash Paul
Text Mining with R: A Tidy Approach by Julia Silge and David Robinson
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
I’m a data scientist and social scientist specializing in political behavior. I’m also a runner, writer, gamer, YouTuber, and dinosaur enthusiast.
